papers.title: Machine Learning and Subjective Assessments by Unemployed Workers and Their Caseworkers
papers.authors: G. J. Berg,Max Kunaschk,Julia Lang,G. Stephan,Arne Uhlendorﬀ
papers.summary: The results suggest that caseworker assessments contain information not captured by the machine learning algorithm, and random-forest machine learning methods are used to predict individual LTU.

papers.title: Using Machine Learning to Create an Early Warning System for Welfare Recipients
papers.summary: Predictive models of income support receipt intensities for any payment enrolee in the Australian social security system between 2014 and 2018 are developed to improve the detection of long-term income support recipients accruing a welfare cost nearly AUD 1 billion higher than individuals identified in the current system.

papers.title: Do Red-Flagged Clients Exit Social Assistance Earlier than Others? The Case of the Finnish Social Assistance System
Fairness in vulnerable attribute prediction on social media
papers.summary: The results show that careful assessment of fairness metrics should be considered when AI models are employed for policymaking, and a framework based on an adaptive threshold for gender is proposed.

papers.title: Predicting the probability of long-term unemployment and recalibrating Ireland's Statistical Profiling Model
papers.authors: S. McGuinness,P. Redmond,E. Kelly,Konstantina I. Maragkou

papers.title: Bias as Boundary Object: Unpacking The Politics Of An Austerity Algorithm Using Bias Frameworks
papers.venue: Conference on Fairness, Accountability and Transparency

papers.title: (in) Accuracy in Algorithmic Profiling of the Unemployed – An Exploratory Review of Reporting Standards
papers.summary: It is demonstrated that the current method of reporting a single measure for accuracy (usually a percentage) inflates the capabilities of the technology in a peculiar way, and so falsely identify those who prove to be frictionally unemployed as likely to be LTU, having important implications for the effectiveness of spending on ALMPs.

papers.title: Interpretable and Accurate Identification of Job Seekers at Risk of Long-Term Unemployment: Explainable ML-Based Profiling
Profiles Among Women Without a Paid Job and Social Benefits: An Intersectional Perspective Using Dutch Population Register Data
papers.authors: Lea Kröner,Deni Mazrekaj,Tanja van der Lippe,A. Poortman
